values.kube_config_raw:
apiVersion: v1
clusters:
- cluster:
    certificate-authority-data: 
    server: https://ecommerce-prod-v1qpimhu.hcp.eastus.azmk8s.io:443
  name: ecommerce-aks-prod
contexts:
- context:
    cluster: ecommerce-aks-prod
    user: clusterUser_ecommerce-rg-prod_ecommerce-aks-prod
  name: ecommerce-aks-prod
current-context: ecommerce-aks-prod
kind: Config
preferences: {}
users:
- name: clusterUser_ecommerce-rg-prod_ecommerce-aks-prod
  user:
    client-certificate-data: 
    client-key-data: 
    token: nbt21s0fju6993zfgb5bzyqkjmjcpu6ajpyfr4keyijs0cll75z0lmue2oac4a9x4mgf7y5rvd7jei767lx8j2vz7yerd5di1zsrmernldxlqjgy6wmo4y9vpwljhfgp
values.name: ecommerce-aks-prod

metadata.name: cert-manager
metadata.notes:
cert-manager v1.13.3 has been deployed successfully!

In order to begin issuing certificates, you will need to set up a ClusterIssuer
or Issuer resource (for example, by creating a 'letsencrypt-staging' issuer).

More information on the different types of issuers and how to configure them
can be found in our documentation:

https://cert-manager.io/docs/configuration/

For information on how to configure cert-manager to automatically provision
Certificates for Ingress resources, take a look at the `ingress-shim`
documentation:

https://cert-manager.io/docs/usage/ingress/

values.name: ecommerce-microservices
values:
global:
  imageTag: 0.3.0
  imagePullPolicy: Always

ingress:
  enabled: true
  host: ecommerce.172.172.180.123.nip.io
  tls:
    enabled: true
    secretName: ecommerce-tls-secret

metadata.name: ingress-nginx
metadata.notes:
The ingress-nginx controller has been installed.
It may take a few minutes for the LoadBalancer IP to be available.
You can watch the status by running 'kubectl --namespace ingress-nginx get services -o wide -w ingress-nginx-controller'

An example Ingress that makes use of the controller:
  apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
  kind: Ingress
  metadata:
    name: example
    namespace: foo
  spec:
    ingressClassName: nginx
    rules:
      - host: www.example.com
        http:
          paths:
            - pathType: Prefix
              backend:
                service:
                  name: exampleService
                  port:
                    number: 80
              path: /
    # This section is only required if TLS is to be enabled for the Ingress
    tls:
      - hosts:
        - www.example.com
        secretName: example-tls

If TLS is enabled for the Ingress, a Secret containing the certificate and key must also be provided:

  apiVersion: v1
  kind: Secret
  metadata:
    name: example-tls
    namespace: foo
  data:
    tls.crt: <base64 encoded cert>
    tls.key: <base64 encoded key>
  type: kubernetes.io/tls

ingress_public_ip.description: Public IP address for the ingress controller

identity_principal_id.description: The principal id of the cluster's systemAssigned identity (control plane)

kubelet_identity_object_id.description: The object ID of the kubelet identity used by AKS

node_resource_group.description: The auto-generated resource group where AKS nodes are deployed

dns_prefix.description: DNS prefix for the AKS cluster

node_count.description: Number of nodes in the default node pool

email.description: Email address for Let's Encrypt notifications

timeout.description: Timeout in seconds for the Helm release

load_balancer_ip.description: Static public IP address for the ingress controller

static_ip_resource_group.description: The resource group where the static public IP is located

aks_key_vault_secret_provider_object_id.description: Object ID of the AKS Key Vault Secrets Provider identity

dns_prefix.description: DNS prefix for the AKS cluster

email.description: Email address for Let's Encrypt notifications

node_count.description: Number of nodes in the default node pool

static_ip_name.description: Name of the static public IP created manually

static_ip_resource_group.description: Resource group where the static public IP is located
